verses.text: David gathered all the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand.
verses.comment: The Hebrew text says 'again', emphasizing a second gathering; 'chosen men' can also mean 'select.'

verses.text: David arose and went with all the people who were with him from Baale-judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which bears the Name, the Name of the LORD of hosts who sits above the cherubim.
verses.comment: Baale-judah is otherwise known as Kiriath-jearim. The Hebrew emphasizes God’s enthronement above the cherubim.

verses.text: They set the ark of God on a new cart and brought it out of the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were driving the new cart.
verses.comment: Traditional Levitical methods required poles, not a cart; this deviation is noteworthy.

verses.text: They brought it out of the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill, with Ahio walking before the ark.
verses.comment: In the Hebrew, it repeats 'out of the house'; some manuscripts add Uzzah went beside the ark.

verses.text: And David and all the house of Israel were celebrating before the LORD with all kinds of instruments made of fir wood, with lyres, harps, tambourines, castanets, and cymbals.
verses.comment: The Hebrew list of instruments varies slightly in ancient translations; 'castanets' is uncertain.

verses.text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, Uzzah reached out toward the ark of God and took hold of it, because the oxen stumbled.
verses.comment: The name 'Nacon' is sometimes given as 'Chidon' in Chronicles.

verses.text: And the anger of the LORD burned against Uzzah, and God struck him there for his error, and he died there beside the ark of God.
verses.comment: The Hebrew word for 'error' may also mean 'irreverence' or 'rashness.'

verses.text: David became angry because the LORD had broken out against Uzzah; therefore, that place is called Perez-uzzah to this day.
verses.comment: Perez-uzzah means 'outbreak against Uzzah.'

verses.text: David was afraid of the LORD that day and said, 'How can the ark of the LORD come to me?'
verses.comment: David's fear results from the severity of God's judgment.

verses.text: So David was not willing to bring the ark of the LORD to him in the City of David; instead, David took it aside to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
verses.comment: Obed-edom is likely a Levite; 'Gittite' may indicate his origin or residence.

verses.text: And the ark of the LORD remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-edom and all his household.
verses.comment: 'Blessed' suggests both material prosperity and spiritual favor.

verses.text: And it was told to King David, 'The LORD has blessed the household of Obed-edom and all that belongs to him because of the ark of God.' So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-edom to the city of David with rejoicing.
verses.comment: Reports of blessing prompt David to bring the ark; 'rejoicing' is prominent.

verses.text: And when those who bore the ark of the LORD had gone six steps, he sacrificed an ox and a fattened animal.
verses.comment: Unlike the earlier use of the cart, here Levites carry the ark as prescribed.

verses.text: And David danced before the LORD with all his might, and David was wearing a linen ephod.
verses.comment: The linen ephod is priestly attire; 'all his might' suggests joyful abandon.

verses.text: So David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouting and with the sound of the trumpet.
verses.comment: Trumpet (ram’s horn) was often used for celebrations and worship.

verses.text: And as the ark of the LORD came into the city of David, Michal the daughter of Saul looked out of the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the LORD, and she despised him in her heart.
verses.comment: Her contempt foreshadows later conflict.

verses.text: They brought in the ark of the LORD and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
verses.comment: David acts as mediator, performing both types of offering.

verses.text: When David had finished offering the burnt offerings and the peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: David’s blessing invokes God's authority.

verses.text: And he distributed to all the people, the whole multitude of Israel, both men and women, a cake of bread, a date cake, and a raisin cake to each one. Then all the people departed, each to his house.
verses.comment: The Hebrew for 'cake' is uncertain; ESV translates as 'portion of meat.'

verses.text: David returned to bless his household. But Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David and said, 'How the king of Israel honored himself today, uncovering himself before the eyes of his servants’ female servants, as one of the vulgar fellows shamefully uncovers himself!'
verses.comment: Michal’s rebuke is biting and sarcastic.

verses.text: And David said to Michal, 'It was before the LORD, who chose me above your father and above all his house, to appoint me as prince over Israel, the people of the LORD—and I will celebrate before the LORD.'
verses.comment: David boldly affirms his divine calling and worship.

verses.text: And I will become even more undignified than this, and will be humble in my own eyes. But by the female servants whom you spoke of, by them I shall be held in honor.
verses.comment: 'Humble' carries the connotation of self-abasement.

verses.text: And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child to the day of her death.
verses.comment: Implied judgment for Michal’s contempt; the Hebrew text is terse.
